author: timhc22
content: I have had a quick skim of the article, I'll read in more detail at some point soon, but (from reading the article), and from some other conversations recently, it seems that web3 is really starting to get to a stage where UX and UI are coming to the forefront, would you agree?

author: timhc22
content:
Quote from a talk yesterday, Ian Lee (IDEO Co-Lab Ventures) on 'Hero moments' being REALLY important, but that it needs to be simple (i.e. good UX/UI) to get there:

* setting up meta mask
* buying first NFT
* joining and then voting in your first NFT DAO
* etc

author: andrewhong5297
content: Completely agree! So much so that I've started taking UX design courses on the side since engineering alone doesn't cut it anymore.

author: andrewhong5297
content: There are so many disparate user flows that it is really hard to design and educate for, on top of engineering for. It isn't just engineering a product that works through one dapp flow, it needs to work with all the possible flows in the ecosystem.

author: timhc22
content:
one of the big ones is ENS in my opinion, I've spoken a few times with the team about it, and they are aware of what is needed, but currently there are 2 steps for getting an ENS domain: setting the record, and then separately setting the reverse record.

If these were consolidated into one flow (and even better, if everyone could be given one for free, #impossible?) then I personally think it would solve a huge part of the onboarding process to Web3. I don't want to assert this too hard though because, the Ethereum team will know better

author: trent_vanepps

author: pipermerriam
content: Not a bother.  I'm running the program for a reason and by my own volition

author: pipermerriam
content: We are not placing any firm restrictions on prior experience or expertise.  The best applicant is one that is intrinsically motivated, capable of learning "all-the-things", and ideologically aligned (working on open source protocols is worth more to you than cashing out big working for Defi or otherwise doubling down on the capitalism game).

author: pipermerriam
content: And there's things that "signal" those things, but ultimately, there's very few firm qualifications that we could put into place that wouldn't potentially filter out the wrong people.

author: Deleted User
content: I see, that's good to hear. I really like this sort of stuff, I'm just inexperienced, so I hope I can find a place in this.

author: pipermerriam
content: The best way to find that place is to be bold.  Join publicly posted calls and lurk.  Ask for invites to calls that sound potentially interesting.  Read the discussions that are happening here in this server.  Ask a clarifying question when you have one.  But mostly, take personal responsibility for your own learning.  When you think you understand something, write it down and post it somewhere public to get feedback on whether you've got it right.
